problem_text:
Let ω(G) denote the set of element orders of a finite group G. A finite group G is said to be recognizable (by spectrum) if every finite group H with ω(H) = ω(G) is isomorphic to G.
∗a) Is it true that for every n there is a recognizable group that is the n-th direct power of a nonabelian simple group?
b) Is it true that there is a nonabelian simple group L such that for every n there is a recognizable group whose socle is the k-th direct power of L for some k ⩾ n?
V. D. Mazurov, A. V. Vasil’ev
answer: ∗a) Yes, it is true (N. Yang, I. Gorshkov, A. Staroletov, A. V. Vasil’ev, Annali Matem. Pura Appl., 202 (2023), 2699–2714).
